title: Polyatomic ion
text:
A polyatomic ion, also known as a molecular ion, is a <a href="Covalent%20bond">covalently bonded</a> set of two or more atoms, or of a <a href="complex%20%28chemistry%29">metal complex</a>, that can be considered to behave as a single unit and that has a net <a href="electrical%20charge">charge</a> that is not zero. Unlike a <a href="molecule">molecule</a>, which has a net charge of zero, this <a href="chemical%20species">chemical species</a> is an <a href="ion">ion</a>. (The prefix "poly-" carries the meaning "many" in Greek, but even ions of two atoms are commonly described as polyatomic.)
In older literature, a polyatomic ion may instead be referred to as a "radical" (or less commonly, as a "radical group"). (In contemporary usage, the term "radical" refers to various <a href="Radical%20%28chemistry%29">free radical</a>s, which are <a href="species%20%28chemistry%29">species</a> that have an <a href="unpaired%20electron">unpaired electron</a> and need not be charged.)
A simple example of a polyatomic ion is the <a href="hydroxide">hydroxide</a> ion, which consists of one oxygen atom and one hydrogen atom, jointly carrying a net charge of <a href="elementary%20charge">−1</a>; its chemical formula is . In contrast, an <a href="ammonium">ammonium</a> ion consists of one nitrogen atom and four hydrogen atoms, with a charge of +1; its chemical formula is NH+⁴
Polyatomic ions often are useful in the context of <a href="acid%E2%80%93base%20reaction">acid–base chemistry</a> and in the formation of <a href="salt%20%28chemistry%29">salts</a>. 
Often, a polyatomic ion can be considered as the <a href="conjugate%20acid">conjugate acid or base</a> of a neutral <a href="molecule">molecule</a>. For example, the <a href="conjugate%20base">conjugate base</a> of <a href="sulfuric%20acid">sulfuric acid</a> (H2SO4) is the polyatomic <a href="hydrogen%20sulfate">hydrogen sulfate</a> <a href="anion">anion</a> (). The removal of another <a href="hydron%20%28chemistry%29">hydrogen ion</a> produces the <a href="sulfate">sulfate</a> anion ().
Nomenclature of polyatomic anions.
There are two "rules" that can be used for learning the nomenclature of polyatomic anions. First, when the prefix "bi" is added to a name, a hydrogen is added to the ion's formula and its charge is increased by 1, the latter being a consequence of the hydrogen ion's +1 charge. An alternative to the "bi-" prefix is to use the word hydrogen in its place: the anion derived from + , , can be called either bicarbonate or hydrogen carbonate.
Most of the common polyatomic anions are <a href="oxyanion">oxyanion</a>s, conjugate bases of <a href="oxyacid">oxyacid</a>s (acids derived from the <a href="oxide">oxide</a>s of <a href="nonmetal">non-metallic elements</a>). For example, the <a href="sulfate">sulfate</a> anion, , is derived from , which can be regarded as + .
The second rule looks at the number of oxygens in an ion. Consider the <a href="chlorine">chlorine</a> <a href="oxyanion">oxyanion</a> family:
First, think of the "-ate" ion as being the "base" name, in which case the addition of a "per-" prefix adds an oxygen. Changing the "-ate" suffix to "-ite" will reduce the oxygens by one, and keeping the suffix "-ite" and adding the prefix "hypo-" reduces the number of oxygens by one more. In all situations, the charge is not affected. The naming pattern follows within many different oxyanion series based on a standard root for that particular series. The "-ite" has one less oxygen than the "-ate", but different "-ate" anions might have different numbers of oxygen atoms.
